title: From ‘Your Honor’ to ‘Tehran’: Why Israeli Dramas Translate So Well to American TV
sub_head: The executive producer of a new Showtime series and another on Apple TV+ talks about the inherent jeopardy in Israeli series
body:
The high-concept premise of Showtime’s new television drama “Your Honor” was made in Israel. The 10-part show, which premiered Dec. 6, stars Bryan Cranston as a spotless New Orleans judge who betrays his ethical code by covering up a hit-and-run involving his son.
Alon Aranya, an executive producer on “Your Honor,” helped shepherd the series to American TV. He says the original Israeli version, “Kvodo,” was made for a fraction of what the U.S. version cost and that its remake rights have also been sold to India, France, Russia, Germany and Italy.
Mr. Aranya, 49, has executive produced several U.S. television remakes of popular Israeli shows, including the CBS series “Hostages” (2013-14) about a doctor whose family is taken hostage as she is about to perform an operation on the U.S. president, which he also co-wrote. However he says his focus has become more international since 2017 when he set up his company Paper Plane Productions with offices in Los Angeles, Tel Aviv and the Netherlands.
Earlier this year, Paper Plane co-produced “Tehran,” which became AppleTV+’s first international show. The 8-part espionage thriller shot mostly in Farsi was co-written by “Fauda” screenwriter Moshe Zonder. Since its September premiere Messrs. Zonda and Aranya each signed first-look development deals with AppleTV+.
